Text: Lovers of heritage should pay a visit to the National Museum of Singapore—home to historical insights and cultural artefacts galore—while budding creatives can find inspiration at the Singapore Art Museum.
Art enthusiasts must take a tour around the Tate Modern, which is a cultural monster and has changing modern exhibits.
Experience the full literature of Shakespeare and immerse yourself in drama at The Globe.
Explore the rich history behind war curiosities and enjoy film installations by the most innovative artists.
This exhibit features specimens that the museum selected from its exhaustive collection for their scientific, historical, aesthetic, and cultural importance.
Australia's largest cathedral is a stellar example of colonial-era architecture and heritage.
Experience the pulse of Malaysia's history with interactive exhibits and immersive experiences at the Chinatown Heritage Centre.
The Heritage Centre is a must-visit if you’re keen on learning about the rich heritage and culture of the Malay community.

The museum is a rich showcase of heritage and culture, with historical artefacts, interactive multimedia and colourful exhibits from the national collection as well as contributions from the community.
Fuk Tak Chi Gallery was once the oldest temple in Vietnam and is an elegant example of restored architecture.
It's theatres feature record-breaking musicals and acclaimed opera performances, and the city itself, with its magnificent buildings and architecture, is like an open air museum for you to explore
Spanning 3 floors with over 1,300 artefacts, the museum is jam-packed with fascinating exhibits.
Fresh-thinking and futuristic, the museum hosts playful and interactive exhibitions for all ages.
Nothing says culture more than art, especially a place that houses centuries of art from all over the world.
It does offer a glance into how art, and society’s definition of art, has changed throughout time.
The museum has strived to educate people on the history of our planet, from it’s living creatures, to the plethora of cultures evolved throughout time.
This mammoth of a museum has 45 permanent exhibition halls, millions of plant and animal specimens, and cultural artefacts.
Perched on the banks of the river Arno in Florence, the Uffizi Gallery is home to some of the world’s most famous Italian Renaissance art.
Temporary contemporary exhibitions run alongside those from the 90,000-strong permanent collection, and there are family-friendly hands-on installations and activities in the Rabo Lab.
The huge collection contains many masterpieces, including works by Dutch masters Rembrandt, Vermeer and Van Gogh, but also everything from ship models and swords to Delftware and dollhouses.
This modernist architectural gem is awash with all things film, including cinemas, vintage posters, exhibitions and artefacts.
The Van Gogh Museum has more than 200 paintings and 500 drawings by the artist, making it the largest collection of Van Gogh artworks in the world.
Locally known as the Museum Het Rembrandthuis, it houses his studio, living room and bedroom, a collection of his curiosities and some of his works.
A tiny, eccentric museum, Electric Ladyland holds a permanent exhibition of fluorescent art, with fluorescent minerals, fluorescent artwork from the 1950s and other glowing artefacts.
A purpose built gallery building on West 20th Street in Chelsea is dedicated to museum-quality shows of historical figures and movements.
Gladstone Gallery is strictly blue-chip, focusing on such Conceptualist and daring talents as Matthew Barney, Sarah Lucas and Anish Kapoor.
This engaging heritage attraction takes you through the history and culture of the Eurasian community.
M Shed is an exciting and innovative flagship museum for Bristol with gallery space and a packed events schedule.
Museum and art gallery exhibiting some outstanding collections of art, archaeology, Egyptology and natural history in a magnificent building
Tour the ship, climb the rigging, head deep into the Dry Dock and meet Victorian passengers and explore two additional museums in the historic dockyard.
Much more than a fascinating building, being a fine example of a hall church, it is a centre of Bristol's history, civic life and culture.
The organisation is dedicated to producing and presenting visual arts, performance, film, music and events.
A unique centre devoted to the production and exhibition of the contemporary visual arts.
Art, natural history and the story of Wales itself are explored in Wales’ national museum.
Learn about the ancient settlers who cultivated this part of the country, how its landscapes were formed and see historical and modern masterpieces.
Home to the largest collection of works by L.S. Lowry, a painter who dealt extensively with industrial scenes, it also houses two theatres.
Explore world cultures through thousands of fascinating objects at the Pitt Rivers Museum, then pop next door to discover wonders at the Museum of Natural History.
Explore Scottish history at the National Museum of Scotland through a host of artefacts dating back hundreds of years.
There are also sections dedicated to art and design, science and nature and a rich variety of world cultures.
The Cornish branch of the Tate galleries is a beachside icon showcasing contemporary art.
Manchester’s museum of art and costume has 25,000 works of art including a notable collection of Victorian and Pre-Raphaelite works.
The museum is also great for kids who love creating their own ‘junk’ art, dressing up as historical characters and playing with the interactive computer exhibits.
Kids and adults will learn about science in a wonderfully involving way at this huge free museum.
Learn the story from prehistory to the present day at this free museum dedicated to one of the world’s most fascinating cities.
Discover its wealth of art and historical objects, from arms and armour to paintings of all eras and movements, and even a natural history section.

Best known for its fabulous collection of Pre-Raphaelite paintings, Birmingham Museum and Art gallery also houses a vast collection of objects from all periods of history, including Ancient Greece and Rome.

The Museum tells the comprehensive story from 65,000 years ago to the present day through compelling objects, ideas, events and displays, focussing on Indigenous histories and cultures, European settlement and our interaction with the environment.

With an annual calendar of stunning major exhibitions, an unsurpassed national collection, a dynamic program of public programs and live art events, the National Gallery is home to the visual culture and spirit of Australia.
The NGV hosts a wide range of international and local artists, exhibitions, programs and events; from contemporary art to major historic exhibitions, fashion and design, sound and dance.
It holds the most significant collection of art in the region; a vast treasury of more than 70,000 works that span thousands of years and a wealth of ideas, disciplines and styles.
Barcelona is full to the brim of Gaudí’s works: the rippling stone of Casa Mila, the skeletal balconies of Casa Batlló, the fantastical pavilions and pathways of Parque Güell.

Extensive renovations, finally complete in 2017, will see the complex fully reopened, with the city’s long and intriguing maritime history recounted beneath the shipyard’s original vast Gothic arches.

The Dali Theatre-Museum's vibrant red walls,topped with golden statues and oversize eggs, house superbly strange and interactive artworks designed, according to Dalí himself, to be a “theatrical dream”.
The idea of combining a modern art museum, library, exhibition and performance space and cinema in one multi-purpose complex was also revolutionary
Pompidou – known to locals as simply ‘Beaubourg’ – contains the largest collection of modern art.
It became a museum proper in 1819 – and contains a vast, fascinating and attractively laid out collection of treasures.
This museum, housed in an extraordinary building by Jean Nouvel, is a vast showcase for non-European art and culture.
A video art and cinema suite in the basement shows new digital installation work, as well as feature-length films made by artists.
Bungy jumping is not something to miss if you love thrilling adventure.
If thrill is what you seek, head to Moab in Utah, known for its mountain-biking and canyoneering routes.
Part skydiving and part cliff jumping, BASE jumping is one of the most extreme thrills you can pursue.
Getting an eagle’s-eye view of Vegas is thrilling in itself, but pulling Gs in an aerobatic plane takes a sightseeing flight to heart-racing new heights.
Try rock-clibing at Yosemite in an activity that will definitely get your blood pumping and palms sweating.
Waken the daredevil in you by ziplining at a high speed above New York's mountains.
If you are brave enough, you can test your mettle by paragliding over Maui.
There are few things more exhilarating than lowering yourself down a rock face amid a deluge of foamy spray.
Be bold and push your limits by skiing off steep vertical descents and difficult routes.
Discover the top outdoor extreme adventures the USA has to offer, that are sure to give you a real buzz.
Cliff diving doesn’t just look awesome on your Instagram — it’s also perfect for adrenaline junkies.
If abseiling down a giant tower sends your heart a-flutter, make for the Euromast
The region’s coastline is a paradise for hardcore explorers, and extreme rock climbing tours are easy to book.
Jumping out of a plane at 15,000 ft (over 4,000 m) is a surefire way to make anyone’s heart rate skyrocket.
Hop on ajetski and face off against the waves of the Atlantic Ocean for an action-packed experience.
If you want to push your boundaries a little further, head to Slovenia where another pulse-raising adventure is waiting.
Base jumping is for the truly courageous, and Kjerag Mountain’s option in this space is no exception.
This is one of the best adrenaline activities for petrol heads and will make you feel like you’re in the middle of an F1 race.
A small gorge in El Chorro, known as the El Camino Del Rey Walkway, is a heart-stopping walking tour.
Hang gliding is one of the best adrenaline activities available, but we warn you: try it once and you might become obsessed.
Hike to the top of cliffs, cruise on the Lysefjord, fish for salmon, or hop on a horse for a riding expedition.
Anyone can zoom down a smooth road, but real thrills come in the form of driving on frozen lakes forwards, backwards and sideways.
Bobsleigh is one of the most popular extreme sports and involves descending down a narrow iced track in a gravity-powered sleigh.
Heli-skiing is one of the best adrenaline activities you can experience on a mountain, but it’s not for the weak at heart.
Climbing can be risky, but for many, it adds to the thrill of scaling frozen mountains in sub-zero temperatures.
A favorite with many thrill-seekers, and an excellent entry-level activity for those new to high-octane adventures, bungee jumping has become one of the most popular holiday pursuits.
Plummeting down to earth at 120 miles per hour usually provides enough of a rush to satisfy even the biggest adrenaline junkie.
You can make your experience even more exciting by combining canyoning with abseiling and cliff jumping.
Looking for some water adrenaline activities? Go cage diving in Cape Town and get up close and personal with jaws and pals.
This is a superhero level of extreme experiences and one of the most unique adrenaline activities to enjoy.
Paragliders and skydivers were looking for something new to push their adrenaline buttons, so they created speed flying.
If you think coming face to face with a shark while you’re in a cage is pushing your limits, just wait until you get in a cage of death.
You will power through narrow river gorges, coming face to face with rocks while skimming across the water in what is a thrillful experience.
For general outdoor adventure in some of the UK’s most beautiful forests check out Go Ape adventure centres
This extreme activity involves hopping, scrambling and jumping your way along coastal cliffs, with some daring cave exploring and swimming thrown in for good measure.
Togged up in a wetsuit, helmet and buoyancy aid, those drops and jumps will certainly test your mettle!
From gentle scrambles to challenging climbs, this extreme activity lets you set your own pace
If you want to immerse yourself in the great outdoors and feel your heart race, you’ll love canyoning.
This adventurous pursuit is a great way to reconnect with your wild side – after all, you’ll be scaling naturally-sculpted rock and feeling the spray from spectacular waterfalls.
White water rafting is one of the most exhilarating experiences around, and there’s no need to be too apprehensive.
This extreme activity isn’t for the faint hearted, but if you can muster up the courage to jump off that platform, you’ll have the thrill of a lifetime.
Saddle up and get that adrenaline pumping: quad biking takes in some of the most challenging terrain
With challenging trails waiting to put your skills to the test, it’s a great way to encourage your family’s competitive spirit.
Once you experience the chilly temperatures, you’ll discover just how exhilarating it can be!
Ample rides make this a thrill-seekers dream.
It is perfect for adrenaline junkies and thrill seekers, but there are limited alternatives for small children.
It has some of the biggest roller coasters and the rides here are built to scare
This indoor adventure boasts 32 exhilarating challenges to test your mental and physical skills.
Visit Mount Huashan in China which features the world’s most dangerous hiking trail.
Along way you will encounter a death defying cliffside plank path which has over a kilometer drop.
Experience the thrill of circling the CN Tower 356 meters above the ground!
Edge walks regularly take place around the roof of its tallest attraction, and if that doesn’t get your blood pumping, the walk is also hands free!
Cerro Negro is a volcano in Nicaragua, and thrill seekers have the opportunity surf down it’s 500 meter descent on a plywood board.
Feel the thrill of riding the high seas on an inflatable race boat.
In this terrifying experience the only thing separating you from the crocodiles is a perspex cage.
This roller coaster will give you an adrenaline rush unlike any other ride you have experienced.
Feel like a hamster with a taste for adrenaline, by going zorbing.
Washington State and northern Idaho are popular places for adventure seeing kayakers, and provide a thrilling free fall.
Take a walk around this lush green wonderland, home to the Cloud Forest and its tropical highland greenery, the myriad flora of the Flower Dome and the surreal Supertree structures.
Unwind with a river cruise on the river Thames on a cosy boat.
Spend an hour or two exploring this magical space and unwind beneath the hanging baskets.
If you’re looking to melt away some of that city tension then the friendly critters at Vauxhall City Farm will be happy to oblige.
The water garden is possibly the best spot for solitude, tucked away from the crowds, where the only noise you’ll hear are ducks flapping their wings in the spray.
As the largest park in the city it remains a firm favourite for a spot of calm away from the snarl of traffic.
Take in the peace and quiet at this calming oasis.
Located on the fifth floor, there are tables and quiet areas where you can sit down, read or relax far above the crowds.
But that’s what makes it all the more enchanting: a truly wild, and seemingly secret, place with hawthorn trees and brambles.
It’s a Thai Buddhist temple but anyone is welcome to visit the temple or walk around in the grounds, and the sanctuary garden is a top spot for quiet.
Located on Granary Square (arguably a quiet spot unto itself), it offers a polar opposite experience to the sprawl and stress around the station.
If you find nature and beautifully manicured shrubbery particularly relaxing, The Huntington Library & Gardens is your perfect sanctuary.
You can stay there from day to night, and actively relax in its intimate urban oasis.
Sitting along The Strand and watching the sun go down is one of my favorite ways to relax.
Relax as the locals do – visit an onsen or hot spring and spend an hour soothing your tensions away.
The Island is literally the most secluded beach spot in Dubai and the comfy loungers, gentle breeze and, well, not much else really, make it an ideal retreat for solitude hunters.
With low humming music, a vibrating bed, mood-enhancing light show and relaxing aromas, it can induce a sense of calm in even the most agitated of souls.
Luxury resort Al Maha is surrounded on all sides by mile after mile of empty sand dunes and that adds to the solitude and refined luxury of Timeless Spa.
A pampering session at a spa combined with a lazy afternoon tea is the perfect combination of relaxing activities as far as we’re concerned.
You’ll be wrapped in an “anti-stress cocoon” and the multisensory experience promises to leave you feeling calm, relaxed and thoroughly invigorated.
Spend a chilled day wandering around the London Wetland Centre in Barnes, exploring 100 acres of lakes, ponds and gardens, spotting birds and pretending you're deep in the English countryside.
For a truly lazy day, you could always opt for a trip on the UK's first Solarshuttle, a magnificent machine which glides silently across London's most beautiful central lake, powered only by the sun.
Head south-east for a day of quiet contemplation and exploring in Southwark.
It's impossible to feel anything but relaxed when you meet the doe-eyed, supremely dignified llamas and alpacas, and the happy horses at Mudchute City Farm.
Beyond swimming, Hyde Park is an idyllic place to go for a stroll through gardens.
Regent’s Park is yet another royal park that is a great option if you’re looking for a relaxing activity.
Can you think of anything more relaxing than cruising down the River Thames?
For a leisurely stroll and relaxing time, the London Zoo is the ideal place to visit.
In some zones, it’s almost a zen-like experience with music playing in the background while sea creatures swim by peacefully in their habitats.
This peaceful trail runs for approximately 2.9 miles and is a haven from the busy London streets.
Step into a secret world and discover 45 green acres where the history of Bristol is told in a leafy and tranquil setting.
Take a stroll to enjoy the overgrown shrubbery and spot the sculptures lurking in the leaves.
There’s something very peaceful about watching ferries, cruise ships and shipping containers slowly making their way across the Channel.
Indulge in the oasis of nature that is Gardens by the Bay, or simply take a relaxing stroll by the water.
Soak in the mineral-rich, warm waters of their onsen (hot spring) baths, which are said to have detoxifying and healing qualities.
Couple that with a herbal compress to relax the nerves and nourish the skin.
When you’re completely engrossed in an action like drawing, you can reach a near meditative state called “flow.”
An incredibly relaxing experience that can allow you to free your mind and reduce anxiety and stress.
The gentle movements of Tai Chi are said to calm the mind and relax the body.
You can also enjoy free flow hot drinks, aromatherapy and soothing music in this relaxing environment as you create your own masterpiece.
With all the things to do in Kuala Lumpur to keep you busy, you are also going to need to give yourself some time to relax.
This tangled patch of hilly, rocky terrain in the heart of the park manages to remain blissfully quiet and crowd-free.
As you stroll along the twisting trails and catch glimpses of the park’s sparkling lake, it’s easy to forget you’re not in the depths of a remote forest with this quiet park setting in NYC.
You can wander through quiet halls, stroll through the decorative gardens, and hike the park’s peaceful trails, stopping to admire sprawling views of the sparkling Hudson River below your perch.
Kitties roam free at a cat cafe, and patrons rent slots of time — from 30 minutes to 5 hours — which they can spend cuddling and relaxing with the little furballs.
The Brooklyn Botanical Gardens offers a welcome, soul-soothing respite.
The park’s paths wind through an idyllic landscape chock full of unique plants and flowers.
Wander to the Japanese Pond with a book and set up quiet camp for an afternoon.
The vibrant colors, the sweet, floral smells and the peaceful quiet of the gardens make visiting this place an experience that engages the senses.
Visiting the garden feels like being transported out of the city—and even the current time period—entirely
This Bronx oasis is sectioned into 50 unique gardens, including the new azalea area and a sublime lilac collection.
Take a load off at the recently opened Muscota Marsh, a new green space with views of the Shorakapok Preserve and the Henry Hudson Bridge.
Ostensibly a memorial to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, the space is also a peaceful albeit small refuge.
Stare contemplatively at the Hudson River from underneath an Italian pergola, wander through a dense forest, or veg out among a bed of spring blooms.
But even with the grave seekers, you’ll have no trouble finding a tranquil place to pull up a patch of grass.
Grab a bench at this walled-off oasis, which feels like a magical country garden dropped into the middle of a bustling city.
For the ultimate spa day, treat yourself to the Honored Time program, a seven-and-a-half-hour experience designed to rejuvenate your body and restore your energy.
Head up to the cliffs of to visit one of the city’s most remarkable hideaways and best places to relax and unwind.

A perennial favorite among food-lovers staying in central Singapore, the chicken at this decades-old stalwart is sufficiently succulent, the rice fragrant yet not too oily, the ginger dip addictive, and the chili sauce well balanced.

Your dinner starts out on the first floor of the three-storey shophouse along trendy Bukit Pasoh with snacks that have been perfected in the kitchen of Sweden’s first three-Michelin-starred restaurant.

They go towards making stunning plates like beautifully cooked marron interjected with puffed Koshihikari rice, Yukimuro snow-aged wagyu covered with ramson, pickled baby pine cones flown in from Russia and the most incredibly balanced dessert of sea buckthorn sorbet served paired with oolong mousse and match meringue.
Choose your ingredients, and wait for your plate to return with deep-fried stuff drenched in gooey mushroom-meat sauce.
You can now have a taste of chef Chan Hon Meng's Michelin-winning dishes at his new quick-service restaurant, Hawker Chan.
Each bowl of nourishing soup comes swimming with vermicelli and slices of pork, kidney, and liver.

There is a distinctly Asian flavour in the variety of sandwiches that draws its inspiration from the traditional Vietnamese banh mi – and selections like The Trad (chicken ham and pate with pickled vegetables) are a testament to the classic.

It might cost a tad more than a standard bowl at any coffee shop but take a bite of the torched char siew, springy egg noodles, tender pork belly, and famous peppery boiled wontons (the recipe has a five-decade legacy) before you make your judgement.
The queue at this nasi padang restaurant stretches out the door even before lunchtime hits.

Inspired by the cuisine of Basque Country, where meats are grilled over hot coals and stews are rustic and hearty – he elevates these homey dishes with techniques he’s learnt cooking at some of the top restaurants in the world.

Chef-owner Shigeru Koizumi prepares Kappo-style cuisine with utmost precision, bringing together his experience cooking at three-Michelin-starred Nihonryori Ryugin in Tokyo and Singapore’s very own two-Michelin-starred Odette.
Expect deftly prepared dishes that use uncommon ingredients like wild rice stem and kanzuri to create flavour combinations that are all at once familiar and novel.
The steak topped with bone marrow and burnt onion is something you'll find on every table, but to leave without chowing down on Burnt End's legendary sanger burger would be a travesty.
Satisfy your sweet tooth at Traditional Haig Road Putu Piring.
Savour the flavour of nasi padang at Hjh Maimunah.
Sample the 30 different varieties of mooncakes available, ranging from the typical Cantonese bakes to those that follow traditional Teochew recipes.
Bite into its flaky croissants and freshly baked sourdough loaves.
Feast on chilli crab that is sweet, savoury, tangy and spicy all in one bite and is best mopped up with deep-fried mantou (bun).

Top of the hit list is the Thai spiced rice salad – a crunchy, chewy tumble of rice clusters (think wet, savoury granola) muddled with whispers of scallions, fresh coriander leaves, slivers of red onion, ginger and creamy whole cashews.
Expect a bold, thrilling menu highlighting the revved-up flavours of modern Jerusalem and beyond – including a truly memorable Moroccan fennel salad with a yoghurty harissa dressing.
This buzzy semi-industrial eatery has a day-to-night vibe that suits all comers and all occasions, from breezy business lunches to dinner dates with drinks.
This Ethiopian cafe bashes out hearty vegan food in a friendly, no-frills setting.
Camera-wielding gastro geeks still line Lexington Street hoping to hashtag London’s finest bao, and there’s always a queue outside this iconic no-bookings eatery – your best bet is a late dinner.

Good calls for cheap eating include donburi rice bowls, tonkatsu, curries and slippery soba noodles with dashi dipping sauce, but it’s worth holding back some cash for the authentic Japanese patisserie.

If you want to eat dinner for under a tenner, stay with the meze or filled pittas – perhaps lamb kofte, lamb shawarma, chicken thighs or cauliflower, piled with pickles, herbs and tahini (plus some Yemenite Dynamite hot sauce for extra oomph)

Budget-conscious punters should go for rib-sticking renditions of the eponymous bibimbap: a warming layered dish of rice, spiced vegetables and meat, topped with a fried egg and served in a hot stone bowl.

There are pig buns, fish buns, custard buns and more, but do order some small dishes too (curry fish balls, chilli tripe or glass noodle salad, say) and bulk things out with a rice pot of beef brisket.
Angela Hartnett’s tiny Pastificio is part café-deli, part wine store and part ‘pasta factory’.
The huge menu can be intimidating – so stick to Cantonese dishes for the best results, and note that seafood is a particular strength.
Still, Café TPT manages to deliver its flavour-packed pan-Chinese bonanza with commendable aplomb
Oozing cheese sandwiches and messy riffs on raclette are the main contenders in the food stakes.
The ‘Straight Up Chik’n’ (a crisp-battered chook fillet topped with herb mayo and pickle) is a useful standby, but there are more fancy riffs too.

Expect affordably priced bowls of vegan rainbow goodness, crammed full of vegetables, tofu or fake chicken – try the jerk combo on brown rice, the udon noodle bowl with char siu ‘crumbles’ or the ‘full English’ with scrambled tofu ‘egg’ etc.
Having a “banana leaf” lunch is a unique and enjoyable experience in Kuala Lumpur.
The casual restaurant is spacious and well-ventilated, ideal for a hot curry lunch.
For a truly local breakfast, brunch or lunch we always take our friends to this kopitiam (casual local coffee shop with a collection of food hawkers) in Lucky Gardens.

Refuel (your stomachs, that is) at Joie by Dozo, a rooftop restaurant that showcases Japanese and European culinary methods and presentation, serving up innovative dishes using unconventional ingredients.
The combination is delicious and warming – the ultimate comfort food.
The city’s food establishments are as basic as they come, serving food bursting with flavours in a zero-frills setting.
A glass of Bordeaux from the extensive wine menu will start you off, before you move on to dishes such as the duck head pâté, ox tongue and flank.

Albert serves meltingly tender cuts of beef, such as brisket, tendon and honeycomb tripe in a beefy broth over rice noodles – the barest sprinkling of pepper and sliced spring onions complete each bowl.

The intimate, wood-panelled restaurant is refined, and serves courses of seasonal Japanese produce, from Hokkaido scallops to swordfish, flounder, big-eyed snapper, sea urchin and the sweetest prawns, in a multi-course meal of the chef’s choosing, featuring appetisers, sashimi, sushi and hot and cold dishes.

Maybe it’s the freshness of the fish, the spicy marinade or the precision with which they’re grilled to create a charred, crispy exterior while the flesh remains moist and flaky; whatever it is, this is the ikan bakar worthy of going the extra mile for (in this case, going up Bukit Petaling at lunch time).

The 20-year-old roadside stall’s roti kosong (plain roti canai) is light and crispy with a slight sweetness; it’s tasty enough to eat on its own, but you’ll want to dip it in the dal, sambal and mutton curry for the full experience.

This highly customisable and affordable roadside burger is a Malaysian icon, and while you can find at least one stall operating in every neighbourhood, some of the finest Ramly burgers can be found at Brother John Burger Stall in Damansara Uptown.
If we had it our way, we’d glaze every centimetre of the meat with the restaurant’s special char siew sauce and eat it on its own without rice.
Loke Yun is a famous Hainanese chicken rice institution in town, serving up its delicious rice – slightly sticky but extremely flavourful, and cooked in rich chicken stock.
The creaminess of the fresh coconut milk also shines atop the finely shaved ice and amidst the green pandan cendol jelly – a combination that makes this local dessert such a favourite.
You may have dined at its outlets across the city (including Lot 10 Hutong) but only this original stall at Petaling Street opens until wee hours in the morning.
The streets of Jalan Alor are one of the most popular places in Kuala Lumpur at night with rows of Thai, seafood, and tze char restaurants flanking both sides of the street.
VCR is a popular cafe amongst the locals and after visiting it, I can see why.
The meat was succulent and our Scandinavian Breakfast Set was equally as hearty.
We were truly spoilt for choice with the breakfast platters, sandwiches, burgers, pastas and salads here, but it’s a great go-to for families or those in big groups!
Putting aside the bonafide Malaysian street food and the chill cafes, the unique dining experiences we had in KL was enough to make me look forward to a trip there again.

Jewish deli in its most nostalgic form can be found at Liebman’s in Riverdale, a small and diner-like institution that’s been serving up kosher pastrami, corned beef, and hot dogs made in-house since 1958.
Mott Haven cafe La Morada is one of the small number of New York restaurants specializing in Oaxacan cuisine.
It has been dishing out homey, traditional Greek cooking in Astoria for years, always with a friendly demeanor.
Chef Ignacio Mattos has a way taking seemingly simple seafood dishes like a tuna tartare or raw clam and making them sophisticated yet creative bites worthy of their splurge-level price tags.
Primarily a gin and cocktail bar, this speakeasy sports the ambience of a conventional British gentlemen’s club in the 1920s.
You won’t be overwhelmed with choice; they serve a trim yet inclusive selection of beers, liqueurs, wine and cocktails.
Exactly what the name implies – a place to sip cocktails in the sky.
The KL superclub comprises several clubs, a VIP bar lounge.
Zouk is no stranger to the clubbing scene, you can’t miss out on one of KL’s best nightlife experience
It is perfect for party-goers who want to switch dance tunes throughout the night as each room play different styles and music genres.
They attract the coolest kids in town with its underground electronic, R&B, techno, trance, and EDM music; together with its enchanting lighting system to set the mood on the dancefloor.
Two full-service bars, a fully-equipped DJ console and good drinks, you’re ready for a great night of dancing.
Dance to the tune of upbeat house, techno, hip-hop, and R&B remixes all night at Kyo.
This Japanese-themed club boasts a 6,000 sq ft space which can fit up to 770 clubgoers dancing to heart-racing, thumping music and party through the night.
It’s a tight space with great music and delicious drinks so let your hair loose and dance moves shine.
Featuring Hip Hop, RnB and commercial music, you and your friends can get down to classic early 2000s tunes and enjoy drinks at affordable price.
We’ve spent just as many nights sipping on cocktails at Havana’s alfresco courtyard as tearing up their dance floor upstairs.

International DJs sometimes spin upbeat tracks for a predominantly young crowd but their slew of retro hits every Friday and Saturday night seeks to bring the nostalgic and the wallflowers out on to the floor.
The cocktail menu is divided into the different eras of the drink’s history, each offering original concoctions and classics with a contemporary twist.
The bar exudes a charming tropical resort vibe, and serves on rum flights and rum cocktails, of course.
We recommend going for one of the fruit-infused G&Ts which are very easy to drink, or if you’re after cocktails the house signature Gin Pahit #2 is the bar’s interpretation of the classic Pink Gin.

One of the first proper speakeasy bars and placing in the Top 10 of the inaugural Asia’s Best Bars list, the discreet Omakase + Appreciate serves complex contemporary cocktails created by award-winning mixologists.
There are also rum ciders and plenty of rum-based cocktails on the menu.
Drinks come by way of contemporary cocktails made with premium spirits, as well as wine and champagnes.
Talented bartenders craft refined contemporary cocktails that showcase local ingredients and flavours.
Instead, the bar is confident in its offerings of a trim yet inclusive selection of cocktails, wine, beer and liquors.
The focus at this laidback bar is whisky, and there are over 400 bottles displayed on shelves around the bar.
Go through the whisky collection, or start with a whisky flight or any of their strong whisky-based cocktails.

This neighbourhood bar is a popular spot for fans of craft beer – the rotation of up to eight options on tap at any one point as well as the fridge which contains even more varieties from craft breweries around the world are huge plus points.
Craft beer specialists Taps Beer Bar offer a range of quality craft brews from all over the world – from popular American and European brands to underrated beers from around the region.
The cocktails at this neighbourhood bar feature inventive use of local and Asian ingredients and quality spirits.
Don’t miss the cocktails at Mr Chew’s Chino Latino Bar – they’re very easy to drink and showcase a sense of playful creativity in their execution.
Co-owned by a group of wine enthusiasts and the bar’s own sommeliers, Private Room is an intimate casual wine bar.

Hip hop, grime and R&B party spot.
Coming from the people behind Leyton-based Signature Brewery, there are 16 taps of keg beer on offer at The Collab for you to work your way through until 1am on the weekend.
Party on down in a mock-Tudor pub that gets surprisingly lively come the weekend.
The Clapham branch of the cocktail bar empire has a cinematic theme, which extends to themed booths and quirky cocktails.
At the weekends, DJs playing everything from funk and soul to deep house tempt in crowds of fashionable locals.
A gangster-themed watering hole slap-bang in the centre of town, you could get up to some mischief at Murder Inc.

Black Rock is a small whisky bar with a great USP, housing an old oak tree that acts as a table but also doubles as a vessel for two 'whisky rivers' you can drink from.
This pub on Borough High Street is one of the few in the area that's still jumping beyond midnight.

Make a late-night trip to this Crystal Palace ale pub with eight pumps, craft beer in the fridge and a 1950s pinball machine you can stay glued to until 2am on Fridays and Saturdays, if you're that way inclined.
Get on the dance floor  of this pub for hip hop, R'n'B and disco nights that suit the young neighbourhood pretty well.
A cheesy soundtrack of dance floor fillers and, um, Queen hits keeps central London party people going until 2.30am on Fridays and Saturdays and 1.30am during the week.
This iconic Camden venue has live jazz and DJs until 2.30am on Fridays and 3am on Saturdays.
The cramped, dingy split-level premises boast a fine jukebox, an extensive range of bourbons behind a well-stocked bar.

Late weekend openings only seal this venue's deal as a party destination.
The fun decor of the Camden party palace definitely suits a late-night rendezvous.
If you’re indulging in an after-hours party here, rest assured that the atmosphere is buzzy.
The Upper Street bar has a tiki theme, a beachy soundtrack and more rum.
Ideal for some late-night good vibrations.

Fabric has established itself as one of the capital's clubbing landmarks – a reputation built through consistently high quality programming that showcases all strands of electronic music underground.
Established in 2010, this excellent Shoreditch venue quickly cemented itself as one of the most on-point clubbing spaces and gig venues.

Upstairs is a main bar with a VIP area, while downstairs hosts the dance floor.

This Brixton club has a similar feel to XOYO: a sleek, dark dance cavern with plenty of space for dancing, and the programming leans very much towards the leftfield side of dance music, it's quality, underground house, techno, disco and bass all the way.
Surrounded by local and international department stores, boutiques, and mega malls on both the ends, Orchard Road is the most famous spot for best shopping.
From budget apparel and electronics to high-end fashion labels and housewares, you can find everything under one roof.

From local brands to international ones which you may have never heard of, everything can be spotted here at a price you might not have to think about twice.
All of these stores here are great places for both buying high-end brands and indulging in offbeat shopping.
This market area is one of the most fascinating and best shopping places for those on a budget.

Made-in-Asia wearables, trinkets, Crocs footwear, arts & crafts, carpets, antiques, home furnishings, and the list of things you can buy here is endless.

Posh and expensive international brands such as Louis Vuitton, Chanel, Celine, Prada, Gucci, Burberry, Jimmy Choo, Marc Jacobs, Cartier, and Armani.

Today, visitors can view a great many ruins from the ancient town, including a well preserved Roman theatre, the Baths of Neptune, remains of the military camp, temples to ancient deities, the forum and even Ostia Synagogue, which is the oldest known synagogue site in Europe.
The wealth of history and architecture, including the Bridge of Sighs and the Doge’s apartments, make the Doge’s Palace a fascinating attraction.
Beyond a shadow of a doubt, nothing represents the sheer power and magnificence of the Empire like this stunning piece of ancient architecture.
One of the best known ancient sites in the world, Pompeii was an ancient city founded in the 6th to 7th century BC
Paestum is a Greco site located south of Naples which contains the stunning remains of three ancient Greek temples which still stand tall today.
The site also contains impressive defensive walls, a forum, the basic remains of a amphitheatre and a number of ancient tombs.
This is a necessary pilgrimage for history buffs, and the ideal starting point from which to take in the remains of the city.
The oldest of fora, the Forum, was once the centre of state ceremony, commerce, law and bureaucracy.
The Pantheon is the best-preserved ancient building.

Look beyond the crown of Queen Victoria and the prodigious codpiece of King Henry VIII, and you’ll find an outstanding example of Norman architecture and the most complete survival of a late eleventh-century fortress palace in Europe.

They’re made up of St Martin’s Church, the oldest parish church in continuous use; the atmospheric ruins of St Augustine’s Abbey; and the breathtaking Canterbury Cathedral, whose gothic towers and beautiful stained-glass windows have survived fire, the Restoration and over 1,000 years of daily use.
It's older than the Great Pyramids, and still largely a mystery.
Declared a Grade I historic building in 1993, this is a historic gem at the heart of the city that is worth your visit.
Dedicated to worshipping King-Emperor Man Cheong and the Martial God Kwan Tai, the Man Mo temple is one of the oldest temples.
Today, this site has been declared a historical monument of Hong Kong, and the original village is now a museum open to the public.

It’s an internationally recognised symbol of the city and source of great pride to anyone.
There really is no excuse not to visit this outstanding achievement of historical preservation.
The 18th-century grade II-listed mansion building.

A narrow, winding, quaint street in it’s historic quarter that draws visitors in droves.

As you wander through the seemingly endless maze of curious-looking plots, ranging from gothic graves to Haussmann chambers and ancient mausoleums.
